Article.ArticleTitle: Characteristics and health impacts of PM<sub>2.5</sub>-bound PCDD/Fs in three Asian countries.

AbstractText: Polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins/dibenzofurans (PCDD/Fs) were ubiquitous, persistent chemical compounds attached to particulate matter in the atmosphere. We aimed to study the characteristics of these pollutants in atmospheric PM<sub>2.5</sub> of three Asian countries, including Taiwan (Taipei), Thailand (Chiang Mai), and Vietnam (Hanoi). We carried out a source apportionment analysis to determine significant PCDD/F contributors in these areas. Multiple media model was conducted to access the health impact assessment. The PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentration in Taipei (n = 7), Chiang Mai (n = 20), and Hanoi (n = 10) were 18.4 ± 6.21 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, 133 ± 49.5 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, and 88.1 ± 12.6 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, respectively. The PCDD/Fs level in Hanoi was 92.4 ± 67.3 fg I-TEQ/m<sup>3,</sup> and in Taipei and Chiang Mai was 5.01 ± 2.39 fg I-TEQ/m<sup>3</sup> and 14.4 ± 13.1 fg I-TEQ/m<sup>3</sup>, respectively, which showed that the higher PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentration was not necessary to follow with higher PCDD/Fs level. In all three cities, the effect of traffic on ambient PCDD/F level was significant (23-25 %). However, we also observed the specific sources of PCDD/Fs in each city during the sampling periods, namely long-range transport (Taipei, 55 %), Biomass/open burning (Chiang Mai, 77 %), and industrial activities (Hanoi, 34 %). In the carcinogenic risk estimation, the highest median total carcinogenic risk was in Hanoi (5.87 × 10<sup>-6</sup>), followed by Chiang Mai (1.06x10<sup>-6</sup>), and Taipei (2.95 × 10<sup>-7</sup>). Although diet was the major absorption pathway, the food contributor of exposure differed among the three areas due to the difference in food consumption composition.
